# Intro to React

<span class="lead"> </span>

React is a UI library that is used in various forms to create complex, rich user interfaces. Facebook had a need to build something that could power their user experiences in such a way that was decoupled and unconcerned when and where the data was received.

React is one of the most popular UI libraries today, and in terms of Single Page Applications many (including the React team) tend to think of the library as the “V” in MVC. That is, the View layer of the Model, View, Controller paradigm. React is a pattern, a mindset, that will help developers that use it, build small, reusable pieces of UI that can be easily put together to make a large scale application.

## [React Components and Component State](../module/recZau7hH8vzww14N)

Components are the building blocks of React applications. We use components to display some data (often called “state”) to the screen for our users. In this module, we will learn how to build components that can hold state to create a great experience for our end users.

#### Objectives:

-   Student should be able to describe ReactJS and the problems that it tries to solve
-   Student should be able to explain what components are and how they work in React
-   Student should be able to explain what state is in web applications and demonstrate how to make a React component stateful
-   Student should be able to change the state of the component with a click listener

## [Composing React Components and Passing Data Via Props](../module/recgzSGQtp2HYwgSR)

As you build bigger applications, you’ll want to start splitting up your app into smaller pieces so that it is easier to work on and maintain. These small pieces you will build are called components. Components will need to share state, so we will learn how to do this with a helper object called `props`.

#### Objectives:

-   Student should be able to use JavaScript modules to export and import components
-   Student should be able to describe props and how data flows in a React application
-   Student should be able to demonstrate the ability to compose React components to build out a UI
-   Student should be able to pass props as dynamic data to a React component

## [Component Side Effects](../module/recKe8PW6ZMwjL1Qg)

Side effects in web apps are very common. It’s important to understand what side effects are so we can handle them properly in our components.

#### Objectives:

-   Student should be able to explain what side effects are in React components
-   Student should be able to demonstrate how to sync side effects with state and props using the effect hook
-   Student should be able to fetch data from an API using the effect hook
-   Student should be able to demonstrate how to clean up side effects in the effect hook

## [Advanced Styling Techniques](../module/recNDoSqyUw3eq1y3)

CSS by itself can be hard to scale in large applications. In this module we will see multiple libraries that have been built to help us style our apps in a lot more scalable way.

#### Objectives:

-   Student should be able to bootstrap a React application with Create React App
-   Student should be able to understand how to style React components using Reactstrap
-   Student should be able to use styled-components to add functional styles to their React Components
